summary: Email chain between Gloria Allred's law firm and a DOJ contact regarding logistical arrangements for a DOJ briefing for Epstein victims represented by Allred. The emails discuss client locations worldwide and concerns about requiring in-person attendance during COVID-19.

persons.name: Gloria Allred
persons.context: High-profile attorney representing multiple Epstein victims; corresponds with DOJ about arranging a briefing for her clients and advocates for remote participation options due to COVID-19.

persons.name: Mariann Wang
persons.context: Attorney at Allred Maroko & Goldberg; assists in gathering and providing the locations of the firm's Epstein victim clients.

persons.name: Diane Aldrich
persons.context: Executive Assistant to Gloria Allred; acts as an intermediary for communication regarding the DOJ briefing invites.

connections.description: Colleagues at the same law firm; Allred introduces Wang as her co-counsel in the email chain.
Aldrich is identified as the Executive Assistant to Gloria Allred.
Allred states she represents multiple clients who are victims of Jeffrey Epstein and is coordinating their access to a DOJ briefing.

events.title: DOJ Briefing Coordination
events.description: Email exchange regarding logistical planning for a Department of Justice briefing for Epstein victims, focusing on client locations and the feasibility of in-person attendance versus remote options.

keyFacts: Gloria Allred's law firm represents multiple Epstein victims located across the United States and in several foreign countries including the UK, Iceland, Norway, and Russia.
The DOJ was planning an in-person briefing for victims in Miami, but Allred argued this was unreasonable during COVID-19 and advocated for secure remote alternatives like a phone line or Zoom.
As of late October 2020, none of Allred's clients had expressed interest in flying to Miami to attend the briefing in person.
The email chain reveals the logistical challenges and victim-centered concerns in facilitating communication between the DOJ and a geographically dispersed group of victims.
